name: Baganda
summary: The kingdom builders and cultural custodians
description: The Baganda people form the largest ethnic group in Uganda and are the core of the ancient Buganda Kingdom. Known for their sophisticated political system, rich cultural traditions, and influential role in Uganda's history, the Baganda have preserved centuries-old customs while adapting to modern times.
proverb: Obutaka bw'omukazi si bwamsigwa - A woman's land is not inherited
subtitle: The Kingdom Builders

content.heading: Kingdom Structure
content.text: The Baganda maintain a sophisticated monarchical system with the Kabaka (king) at its center, supported by chiefs and clan leaders who govern different aspects of society.

content.heading: Clan System
content.text: Society is organized around 52 clans (ebika), each with its own totem (muziro), taboos, and ancestral lands that define identity and marriage customs.

content.heading: Luganda Language
content.text: Luganda serves as both the native language and lingua franca of central Uganda, known for its tonal complexity and rich proverb tradition.

content.heading: Oral Traditions
content.text: Stories, proverbs (engero), and praise songs preserve historical knowledge, moral teachings, and cultural values passed down through generations.

quote.text: "Omukama w'eggwanga ye Kabaka" - The king is the leader of the nation
quote.subtext: This proverb reflects the central role of the Kabaka in Baganda society and governance.

clothing.title: Gomesi
clothing.description: The elegant traditional dress for women, featuring a square neckline and sash

clothing.title: Kanzu
clothing.description: Men's formal white robe worn during important ceremonies

food.title: Luwombo - The Royal Delicacy
food.description: Luwombo is the signature dish of Buganda, traditionally prepared by steaming meat, fish, or chicken with vegetables and groundnut sauce wrapped in banana leaves.

details.heading: Cultural Significance
items: Originally prepared only for the Kabaka

featured.name: Mukasa
featured.description: Mukasa is one of the most important traditional names in Buganda, associated with lake spirits and divine protection.
featured.context: Connected to Mukasa, the god of Lake Victoria and fertility in traditional Baganda religion.

name: Alur
summary: Highland people with a rich history of chiefdoms
description: The Alur are a resilient highland people from the West Nile region of Uganda, distinguished by their sophisticated chiefdom system and profound spiritual connection to the mountainous terrain they call home. Known for their warrior traditions and skilled craftsmanship, the Alur have maintained their cultural identity while serving as guardians of Uganda's northwestern frontiers.
proverb: Wang ma gweno pe neno, gweno neno - What the eye of a chicken doesn't see, the chicken sees
subtitle: The Highland People

content.heading: Chiefdom Structure
content.text: The Alur maintain one of Uganda's most sophisticated traditional governance systems, with hereditary chiefs (Rwodi) who serve as both political and spiritual leaders of their communities, bridging ancient wisdom with modern administration.

content.heading: Mountain Guardians
content.text: Living in the highland regions along the Congo border, the Alur have developed unique agricultural and cultural practices adapted to mountainous terrain, making them expert cultivators of highland crops and skilled metalworkers.

content.heading: Luo Heritage
content.text: As part of the larger Luo language family, the Alur share linguistic and cultural connections with communities across East Africa, while maintaining their distinct highland identity and traditions.

content.heading: Oral Traditions
content.text: Alur history is preserved through powerful oral narratives that tell of migrations, battles, and the establishment of chiefdoms, with specialized storytellers keeping these traditions alive across generations.

quote.text: "Rwodi mar alur - tek ma tiyo kod jogi"
quote.subtext: "The Alur chief works together with the people" - This proverb emphasizes the collaborative leadership style central to Alur governance.

clothingDetails.title: Traditional Warrior Attire
clothingDetails.content: Alur warriors traditionally wear distinctive leather garments decorated with cowrie shells and metal ornaments. The iconic war shield (lwedo) features geometric patterns that identify clan lineage and spiritual protection.

clothingDetails.title: Ceremonial Dress
clothingDetails.content: During important ceremonies, Alur people wear elaborate headdresses made from feathers and beads, with colorful cloth wraps that indicate social status and ceremonial role within the community.

foodDetails.title: Highland Cuisine
foodDetails.content: Alur cuisine reflects their highland environment with hearty root vegetables, mountain greens, and river fish. Meals are communal affairs that strengthen family bonds and community relationships.

columns.heading: Signature Dishes
items: **Malakwang** - Wild vegetables cooked with ground simsim
**Boo** - Fermented millet bread, a highland staple
**Ngara fish** - River fish prepared with local herbs
**Sweet potato dishes** - Various preparations of highland tubers

columns.heading: Cultural Significance
items: Seasonal foods connect people to the land
Special foods for ceremonies and rituals

traditionsDetails.title: Sacred Ceremonies
traditionsDetails.content: Alur ceremonial life centers around the installation of chiefs, seasonal festivals, and life transition rituals that connect the living with ancestral spirits and ensure community harmony.

columns.heading: Chief Installation
columns.text: The ceremony of installing a new Rwodi involves ritual purification, ancestral invocation, and community blessing. Sacred objects are passed down, symbolizing the continuity of leadership and spiritual protection.

columns.heading: Harvest Celebrations
columns.text: Annual harvest festivals include traditional dances, communal feasting, and gratitude ceremonies to mountain spirits who bless the highland crops with abundance.

namesDetails.title: Traditional Names
namesDetails.content: Alur names carry deep cultural significance, often reflecting circumstances of birth, family lineage, spiritual beliefs, or aspirations for the child's future within the community.

placesDetails.title: Cultural Landmarks
placesDetails.content: The Alur homeland features sacred sites, historical settlements, and natural landmarks that hold deep spiritual and cultural significance for the community.

columns.heading: Sacred Sites
items: **Pakwach** - Historic crossing point on the Nile

columns.heading: Cultural Significance
items: Sites of historical battles and victories

name: Lango
summary: Plains people known for their hunting and farming skills
description: The Lango people are master cultivators of the fertile plains of north-central Uganda, renowned for their advanced agricultural techniques and legendary hunting traditions. Their society celebrates the harmony between human settlement and the natural world, with customs that have evolved from centuries of successful adaptation to the savanna ecosystem.
proverb: Apwoyo pe dong iye abila - A rabbit does not return to a burnt field
subtitle: The Plains People

name: Karamojong
summary: Pastoralist warriors of the semi-arid plains
description: The Karamojong are a proud, semi-nomadic pastoralist people from the semi-arid plains of northeastern Uganda, renowned for their fierce warrior traditions and deep cultural attachment to cattle.
proverb: Akinu ngesi akolong - The sun is the shield
subtitle: The Warrior Pastoralists
